item.title: Episode 468: Should I take a mini-retirement and doubling down on anachronisms
item.description: In this episode, Dave and Jamison answer these questions: Hi Dave and Jamison, Long-time listener, first-time question asker. Thank you both for the wisdom, perspective, and jokes you bring to the podcast. I recently received an inheritance of around $500,000. It‚Äôs not ‚Äúquit your job and buy a yacht‚Äù money, but it is enough to reshape my life. I‚Äôm in my late 30s, currently working in a senior engineering role. I‚Äôve had a solid run in the world of code, but I‚Äôm ready to walk away from it, zero regrets, just done. What‚Äôs pulling me now is UX and product design: more creative, human-centered, systems-aware work. I‚Äôve applied for a one year master‚Äôs program in UX design, starting in 2026. I‚Äôm planning a sabbatical before that to travel, reset, and explore - think trains across Canada, a design conference in Vienna, a food tour in Greece. I‚Äôm also investing in short courses and portfolio work during that time. Financially, I‚Äôve been careful: I paid off my mortgage, invested part of the inheritance, and set up a buffer. So I‚Äôm not winging it‚Ä¶ but I am stepping away from a six-figure salary, a career my friends and family have supported me to build, and am will have no income for the next 18 months, and that‚Äôs a little scary. I want to use this opportunity well, not just coast, or panic-spend, or accidentally put myself in a worse position five years from now. How would you approach this kind of mid-career pivot with a windfall cushion? Any mental models, risk assessments, or ‚Äúsoft skills‚Äù wisdom to help me stay brave and smart? Thanks again for everything you put out into the world. Hi Soft Skills Engineering Team, I‚Äôm the oldest person on my team (by a respectable margin), and I‚Äôve been taking great delight in gently baffling my younger colleagues with expressions like ‚ÄúI‚Äôll get that done in two ticks,‚Äù ‚Äúgive me a bell if you need help,‚Äù and ‚Äústay on the line after stand-up‚Äù (even though we‚Äôre on Teams, not a landline). It has become a bit of a sport for me to see how many retro, obscure, or regionally-specific phrases I can sneak into our chats and meetings before someone finally asks, ‚ÄúWhat are you even saying?‚Äù My question is: What other delightfully old-school and vaguely professional expressions can I deploy to maintain my status as the team‚Äôs resident linguistic cryptid? Thanks for all the great advice you give, and for validating my mission to keep corporate life interesting! Warmest regards, Resident Old Person

item.title: Cloudflare Drops the Hammer on AI Crawlers
item.description:
The big tech company conferences continued this summer with Vercel hosting Vercel Ship 2025. As you‚Äôd expect there was lots of talk about AI and Vercel‚Äôs AI Cloud: tools, infrastructure, and platform enhancements to build AI agents and help AI agents use Vercel. On July 1, hosting platform Cloudflare declared Content Independence Day, and changed its settings to block AI crawlers by default unless they pay creators for their content. While we absolutely support this move, Cloudflare‚Äôs future vision of a marketplace where content creators and AI companies come together and compensation is based on how much content ‚Äúfurthers knowledge‚Äù seems idealistic, but we‚Äôll have to wait and see. Serverless Postgres database company Neon has a new product called Neon Launchpad that can create an instant Neon database with zero configuration or account creation. Users get an automatically generated connection string, 72 hours to claim a new database, and even automatic database seeding with SQL scripts for schema and data initialization. Timestamps:

item.title: Brendan O'Brien - n0, Iroh and the Future of Peer to Peer
item.description:
This week we're joined by Brendan O'Brien (b5), founder and CEO of n0, the company behind Iroh - a peer-to-peer networking library that prioritizes reliability and "just works." Iroh enables developers to establish direct, authenticated connections between any two devices using only their public keys, achieving near 100% connection success rates. We discuss the pragmatic approach to P2P networking, why they chose to focus solely on the transport layer, and how Iroh is already running in production on hundreds of thousands of devices.
